headline: Bread and Butter Pickles
description: Homemade bread and butter pickles are a great way to end summer! Cucumber, onion, peppers, and garlic are pickled in a spicy cider vinegar mixture.

video.description: Add crunch to your lunch with your own homemade pickles.
video.name: How to Make Bread and Butter Pickles

name: Bread and Butter Pickles

recipeInstructions.text: Mix cucumbers, onions, green bell peppers, garlic, and salt together in a large bowl. Allow to stand approximately 3 hours.
Mix sugar, cider vinegar, mustard seed, turmeric, celery seed, and whole cloves together in a large saucepan; bring to a boil over high heat.
Drain any liquid from the cucumber mixture. Stir cucumbers into the boiling vinegar mixture. Remove from heat shortly before the combined mixture comes to a boil.
Transfer into sterile screw-top jars; seal and chill in the refrigerator until ready to serve.

review.reviewBody: Great recipe. Great tasting!
Great recipe

So tasty! Exactly the right spice combination for a crunchy pickle. I did a 10 minute waterbath so they would last without a refrigerator. I loaded the jars first then poured the hot brine over, and debubbled. Made 9 pints this afternoon and already a pint gone before supper. Now the hunt is on for more cukes!
Added a few more mustard seeds and a bay leaf. I used Vidalia onion in one batch and purple onion in the other. Both batches were awesome! Best recipe ever!

This is an easy recipe to make and the completed pickles are excellent tasting! I made one batch with the green peppers and one batch without. Both batches tasted great! So, if you’re not a fan of green peppers, leave them out and you’ll still have some excellent tasting pickles
My mother and husband love this recipe!!!

Did someone forget to say rinse??? I remember these from my mom's canning. The house smells amazing and I was looking forward to the sweet crunch of this childhood memory. I must say, I don't remember them being this salty. These are extremely salty! I'll make this recipe again because the pickles are crunchy and sweet, but I will rinse them and rinse them again to wash off the excess salt. The cucumbers absorb a lot of the salt while resting, and I let them drain well. I also think I'll cut the amount of cloves in half as they are coming thru robustly.
Yummy and crunchy! The only difficulty I had was reducing the proportions to make a smaller batch. But even so, they came out well.
I made these with my mother last week and after letting sit for 4 days, I was stoked to taste...They turned out amazing!!!

These pickles are delicious! I made 1/3 of the veggies in the recipe and 1/2 of the syrup. It worked out perfectly to two quarts with a tiny bit of syrup left over. The pickles are crispy. I used both pickling cukes and regular 8" cukes, both sliced to about 1/8" or less. Next time I will reduce the sugar a bit to see what happens.
I had never canned anything and this recipe was SO easy! The pickles were fantastic, and the instructions were very easy to use. I will definitely be making more!

Excellent, read Elizabeth Fowler's review. Use pickling spice and then they are not too salty. I used the liquid from the soaking as well. It was not a lot. I used pickling cucumbers. I Will be making these again
Agreed, Best Bread and Butter pickles ever. Thanks for sharing!

These bread and butter pickles are amazing! This was my first time making homemade pickles. I followed the recipe exactly. I made these pickles back in August and cracked open a jar today to snack on. They are still nice and crunchy. I am saving this recipe for sure and will make it again this year! Thanks for the awesome recipe!

My mother in law passed this recipe on to me because I loved the batch she made! We hot water bath can ours - here's how: 1/4" head space in glass canning jars, with new lids and bands. 10 minutes in boiling canner. We use sweet red peppers and/or orange and yellow instead of green peppers. Delish!!

This recipe was really tasty and super easy for a first-timer! The only change I recommend is pouring the heated vinegar mixture over the top of the cucumbers instead of the other way around as the recipe calls for (there didn’t seem to be nearly enough liquid in the pan to properly reheat once the cucumber mixture was added).
These taste great. They may not look the prettiest but they taste fabulous! Crispy! First time I ever made pickles
This is so good! The brine turned a reddish color from the tumeric but who cares as long as it taste great right!? Not as crunchy as I would like.
Best pickle recipe...period!! I have canned many pickles and have tried numerous recipes in search of the "perfect" pickle. I stopped here...this is amazing!

I give it a 5-star rating ONLY after adjusting as follows: Way too much salt! Had to toss my first batch, we couldn’t eat them! I use 1/8 -1/4 cup salt instead of 1/2 cup, then rinse well after 30 minutes instead of waiting 3 hours and only draining fluids. Pickles come out crispy and delicious, so much so that friends and family are paying me to make them their own full batches (I only charge for supplies/ingredients). Other than the salt issue, the recipe produces well-rounded flavor and extremely scrumptious pickles!

I give this 4.5 stars! I made these and I am very pleased! I did change it a bit, I only used half the salt ( even with pickling salt they were plenty salty), and added some ginger. I also used a bit more celery seed as it seemed to need it. I ended up with seven pints, but had enough of the pickling juice I could have done one or two more pints if I’d had the cucumbers. I am allergic to peppers so I omitted those and just used more cukes. I also let them salt soak for about 6 hours before I drained them, made them very crunchy! They are very tasty pickles!! Slicing the onions VERY thin on my mandolin really made them pop! I also used purple onions, I really like them! Thanks for the recipe!! I always tweet recipes, so I hope you aren’t offended! This is a really good recipe!

These are good but no way does it make 8 quarts unless you use GIANT cucumbers. I used 35 to 40 nice pickling cucumbers and came out with 5 PINTS! I had lots of brine left so will boil that up again today and make another batch. I watched the video after I was done and the cucumbers did look quite large...too large in my opinion.
Wasn’t too bad had to make double batch for all the cucumbers

These are amazing! I don't usually like bread and butter pickles, but I have an abundance of zucchini and squash this year and somebody said I MUST make bread and butter pickles. I chose this one because of the good reviews. They're not wrong! These are really, really good! I made them as written minus the peppers.

Great recipe, easy to follow, and delicious results. We used a mandolin to slice the cukes which was fast and kept them consistent.
WINNER!!
Perfect! The family loved them
I’ve been making these pickles for years. I use zucchini in place of the cucumbers. I also rinse the vegetables when I drain them so the pickles are less salty.

I had 100 pds of cucumbers and I think I counted 20 cucumbers or 15. I followed except I only used 4.5 cups of sugar and added 2 tablespoons of peppercorns and 1/4 teaspoon red pepper. They don't taste get sweet or spicy. Next time I'll double the spices.
Delicious!
So good! Much better than store bought pickles.

We've made these multiple times and love them. Here's a little clarity on the quantities to de-mystify the process(just based on our experience). We halved the recipe and used 14 cucumbers, they are dill cucumbers we grew, each between 6-8" and fat. 1 1/2 vidalia onions, so a LARGE onion(3 onions would be right if you use standard white or yellow onions), and all other quantities we left as recommended when the recipe is halved. Wish we'd weighed the cucumbers, but we didn't. Did not use green pepper. This made 16 4oz jars so right on target for what the recipe says it will yield. Water bath canned them for 10 minutes. Enjoy the recipe, it's a keeper!

Wow, I absolutely loved this recipe, my pickles turned out perfect. The only thing I did differently was add ice to my pickle mixture while it was basking in the salt and I used less of the whole cloves.
This is the best recipe on this app. Better than anything I’ve been tried in the stores!
First time making pickles. They are so delicious. My husband compared them to his grandmother’s. The jar was empty in less than hour.
Didn't change anything apart from halving the ingredients. Turned out perfect both times I have made it.
Followed the recipe exactly and turned out perfect. Key to keeping them crisp is once you put the cucumbers in, is getting them off the heat BEFORE it returns to a boil. Made about three pint jars.
I scaled it back as I only wanted a small batch. It was delish!
Perfect Blend
Excellent! I will make it again.
I would use less sugar, probably 4 to 4 1/2 cups, good recipe, I processes them 30 minutes in a boiling, water bath canner to be able to store them.

I made it without the green peppers. They turned out great. My son, grandson, neighbor have demolished the first batch
 I am making a second batch now .

I made as listed the first time and canned the pickles. They were great! The next time, I used sweet pickling spice instead of the listed spices, but kept the vinegar and sugar the same and used the brine for beets. The next go round with cukes and beets I cut the salt to 2 T canning salt. Makes delicious beets that last forever after canned.

I have never made a pickle in my life, but tried this one based on reviews from others. They are fantastic. Using pickle cucumbers and pickling salt, I was able to produce 6 pints and 2 quarts of delicious pickles. Will definitely try this one again probably adjusting from cooking onions to sweet onions. Considering I got 35 cucumbers for $7 at the market, these are a bargain to make! Thanks so much.

Very close to Mom's recipe (that I lost), but a little too salty. I do remember my Mom soaking her sliced pickles in the ice/cold brine overnight, prior to adding to the hot vinegar mixture. A very tasty pickle though. I enjoy as a quick snack, in potato salad, mixed greens salad, egg salad, or on a hamburger. Love your recipe varieties. A fabulous site. Thank you.
I haven't tasted yet have to wait a little bit longer
Easy to make and this was my first time ever canning. And the smell is incredible.

You should read the reviews first. Hubby gave up after step 1 because he had more questions than answers. Examples: it's called sweating the cucumbers, doesn't specify canning salt but that's what's recommended, and use pickling cucumbers, the regular kind are too big. We made 1/5 of the recipe and the amount of liquid isn't enough to cover the veggies. I'm new to pickling and this recipe was nothing but frustration, thank goodness I read ahead so I had a clue! The result is just meh.
First time making pickles and these were yummy
easy enough to make.
These are delicious and easy to make!

I’ve made these twice now. Very good. Did not use cloves or green peppers, personal preference only. Otherwise followed closely. Did two large bowls of pickling cukes, sliced with a mandoline, 3 large onions per bowl, plus garlic. Added 1/2 cup pickling salt to each bowl. Mixed well, added a bunch of ice, let sit for 3-4 hours before draining and rinsing. After cooking the cukes in the brine, I filled the sterilized jars and processed in hot water canner. 18 pints. Beautiful! Thank you for the recipe!
Delicious!! I only made a half batch. Next time I will make a whole batch because everyone wants some.
This was the first ever pickle I have made and canned. Very easy to make and it is delicious. Definitely a keeper recipe according to my family.
Love love love these, reminds me of my grandma's pickles. I did lightly rinse the salt off after the soak. They can very well and I have made these (minus the cloves because I hate cloves) 5 times.
no changes to the recipe and they turned out very good. Gave out several jars as gifts and received high praises and they wanted more.
These turned out fine. I used pickling salt but still had to rinse the cucumbers after letting them stand for three hours. They would have been terribly salty.

If I could give these pickles 6 stars, I would. I added ice while the cucumbers, peppers and onions were sitting for 3 hours to make sure the were crispy. My husband wanted me to make dill pickles, but once he tasted these he asked me to use all of this years cucumbers for these bread and butter pickles. He said we'll do dill next year (ha). I'm on my 3rd batch so far. Yum!

Last summer our garden produced an abundance of yellow squash, so I made twenty jars of these pickles with just that one substitution. My family are asking how long it will be until this summer's crop is ready.. "More pickles!" They are the best!!!

I was shocked at how terribly these turned out. Onion to Cucumber ratio is off plus the Cucumber to Liquid ratio was way off. I even doubled the liquids and it was still not enough. As another reviewer mentions, having a weight of cucumber would make it easier to get things right as the only way that I can see 25 cucumbers as being right to the amount of liquid this recipe calls for is if they are mini gherkins. Maybe this is a recipe that a seasoned pickled can make work, definitely not for a beginner like me. Had to toss the whole batch out as it was inedible and certainly not sweet as I would expect a Bread and Butter pickle to be.
Excellent. Very crisp, full of flavor and more than addictive.

I made these and they taste great, however I am giving only 4 stars as I have no Idea how many cucumbers to use. The recipe should give the amount in oz and not just 25 cucumbers. This is misleading and vague as no cucumber have the same size. Anyway, hope someone can clear this out!!
Very tasty. Would recommend to be a great recipe for beginners as well.
Excellent recipe!
I’ve been making this recipe for years, it does have a typo error, the turmeric is suppose to be 1 1/2 teaspoons.
I used red pepper instead of green, and adjusted recipe since I didn't have 25 cucumber at once.
Great recipe. Turned out just the way I like them. Not to sweet & with a crunch

I would love to try this recipe. It looks great, but the ingredient list is too general on vegetable size for me to feel confident that I am using the right amounts. The cucumbers I bring in from my garden seem to range from a couple of ounces to a couple of pounds, and onion size varies a lot, too. It would be really helpful to give the total weights of veggies desired to help out.

Im in the camp of making these less sweet than they are- That being said, the only thing I changed was reducing the amount of sugar to 3.5 cups, and switched out one red bell pepper for a green one- everything else remained the same. My family loves this recipe, and this is the second year I'm canning them
Drain and rinse the cucumbers with water unless you want your dish sweet, sour and salty!

I followed the recipe exactly with the following exceptions: 
I didn't have 25 cucumbers, but I did have 10 extra huge cucumbers from my garden that were each as long as my forearm. I opted to use Pickling Salt rather than table salt. I cut back the Turmeric from 1 tablespoon to 1/2 a teaspoon. I omitted the red peppers and onion slices, and chose to add pearl onions instead.

This yielded exactly 4 quart sized mason jars of pickles.
Great simple recipe. I make twice as much of the liquid to put into the canning jars since I hot water bath these for 15 minutes and store the over the winter. My family loves these pickles.

These are the best Pickles I’ve ever made! I used 1 cup less of sugar and 1 extra cup of vinegar. I loosely measured the spices, and put 2 cloves of garlic in each jar instead of in the veggies. This made 4 quart jars of pickles. I sliced some lengthwise for sandwiches. I am going to try other garden veggies with this juice!
Absolutely wonderful, easy, I will make these again.
I haven't tasted them yet
I substituted some white vinegar and some brown sugar because I live on the edge. Fantastic!
This is my go to recipe for sweet fire! Throw in a couple, or more, jalapeños and poof!...We'll after a couple days of course!

thank you David !!everyone loves this recipe .. did do some things different than recipe .. sorta.. figured a given that wasn't in recipe was to wash the salt off before putting into the liquid mix.. then water bathed them like my dills so I could store out of fridge safely .. but everyone who has tried them have nothing but good things to say .. thank you for adding it here . even my mother in law likes me now .. lol
Great recipe. I haven't had pickles come out this good in a long time!
raves by family and friends

Very good recipe will make it again. I did not have pickling salt so i used kosher salt. I also rinsed the cucumbers well before adding them to the brine. It was delicious.

I did halve the recipe as I only had about 10 to 12 of the little pickling cucumbers. It still turned out great. The flavor is good and the pickles were crisp. Not overly sweet like the store bought kind I loved the flavor.
i went ahead and put mine in a water bath so i didnt have to keep them in the refridgerator.
Followed the recipe. Loved it! Thanks for sharing.
Excellent and easy recipe
These are the Best Bread and Butter Pickles Ever!....Next year I am making up twice as many!
all I did was add ice to the cucumbers and it was great

These are Excellent! My husband and I have tried canning Bread and Butter Pickles before and they turn out too soggy. After Reading the reviews of slicing and making within 24 hours of picking has really helped. Also sitting them in Salt and a bag of ice really does the trick of keeping the cucumbers crunchy. I will definitely make them again. I have given a jar to several of my neighbors and said they could not stop eating them, they are so good.

I used small pearl onions this time, and it looks gorgeous lined up in the pantry. When I made this last year, I found it terribly salty, even though I rinsed the cucumber slices. This year I rinsed and rinsed and rinsed again, and the pickles are much more edible that way.

I also heat processed them after packing them in the brine. They last beautifully, and I've just opened the last jar from last week.
Theses bread and butter pickles are wonderful. I did as another suggested and rinsed the veggies before cooking them and I had a mix of hot and sweet peppers to put in it. They are perfect!

This is what I did because I grew lemon cucumbers, and I did not find many recipes for them. I ended up with 13 pounds of sliced cucumbers so I increased the quantities of the components by 33% except for the salt. Additionally, I only used 1/2 cup of kosher salt. I also used a cooler for the salt bath and put some ice on the top to keep cool (I used an igloo cooler and the ice did not melt, it was 78 degrees in the house). I tasted the cucumbers after the salt bath and they we not overly salty (I do not like a lot of salt in my food). I also used what was in the house: red and white onions, and red frying bell peppers. I ended up with 14 pints of processed pickles with very little left over. The pickles are crunchy. This is my third attempt at making pickles with lemon cucumbers, but it is my favorite so far.
Delicious

I followed the recipe exactly and I knew they were great when I couldn't stop eating the leftover syrup, it was so good

We let them sit 4 weeks at room temperature before eating, my wife and I nearly ate a pint jar when we opened! 

Just be sure to do the hot water bath to preserve but I suspect the next batch will be gone weeks after opening !

These are excellent pickles. They taste so good, I sometimes have a few by themselves at night, just to satisfy my sweet tooth! I made them for the second time today. The first time, I had used red onions, sliced in rings. The pickles are delightfully crunchy, and the red onion added nice color The second time I made this recipe I expanded on the color variation by using miniature yellow peppers, in addition to thinly sliced green peppers.. The color of the finished product is very nice. In terms of specific suggestions, the quantities in the recipe are not exact. For bread and butter pickles, I generally use larger cucumbers and slice them very thinly. The total quantity of cucumbers plus pepper plus onion should be about 1 gallon, for the amount of liquid generated by this recipe.

Really happy with how this turned out. Next batch I am going to dial it back on the onion and the mustard seed. I'm not saying that the measurements on these were wrong, it's just a personal preference. Would definitely recommend trying this recipe out.

Excellent recipe! For those of you that are hot and spicy fanatics, like many in my family, I divided the batch into regular, and hot and spicy. For the hot and spicy, I added a few habanero peppers (5 to be exact) after I made up the regular jars. Throw in a tablespoon of red pepper flakes and ta-da...hot and spicy sweet pickles.
The flavor was very good on this but the ratios all wrong. I didn't use pickling cucumbers so could be why. Too many veggies for not enough brine. Will try again.

This is my first ever attempt at making pickles. My mother hated pickles, so, though she taught me volumes about cooking, I was on my own on this one. I did follow the recipe pretty closely, but took a few tips from other reviewers as well. My only changes were to add a half teaspoon of whole allspice, I used red bell peppers for the color, and I covered the salted cucumbers in a layer of ice while they were brining. I ended up with 7 pints of beautiful, crunchy, delicious pickles! I did water bath process them for 10 minutes so that I could store them in the pantry. I think even my pickle-hating mother would be proud!

I have used this recipe for the past 40 years- it's that good! Several years ago I tasted a similar pickle but it was hot- I loved it and decided I would modify this recipe to try to duplicate it. I added 1/2 tablespoon of red hot chili pepper flakes to the brine and 1/2 of a jalapeño pepper with seeds to each jar. WOW- this modification is a gourmet delight for anyone who likes that extra dimension of peppery heat.
Super easy (although duration of time is long due to soaking); so delicious I'm eating pickles like they are candy!

I followed the recipe to a T and must say these are by far the nastiest pickle I have ever eaten. Waste of time and money as I emptied all the jars in the trash. I mean kerosine cucumbers bad. Maybe I did something wrong but this eliminates the chance of me ever making homemade pickles again. I will just go to the store from now on.
